div.head: LORD CROMER'S REPORT.
div.p: Lord Cromer's report for 1906 is at last before us, ad the rumours of its great interest and importance have proved more than justified. It is a remarkable document, frozi whatever point of view it may be regarded and we are convinced that it will make a profound impression on all its readers, for it diseusses with a remarkable frankness and plainness of speech all those questions which the events of the past year have invested with a more than academic importance Egyptian Nationalism and its aims disguised or avowed, the extraordinary vigour, to use a mild 'term, of the criticisms of the Pan-Islamic Press, above all the great question of the Capitulations are all discussed with admira' le lucidity and strength. We expect that the European colonies in Egypt will be most interested in the last mentioned of these issues. Many of us-perhaps too many--are inclined to regard frontier incidents with indifference, t. ask no questions as to the political future of Egypt, to regard most forms of Egyptian Nationalism with mild amusement or bored acquiescence, and to concern ourselves only with the affairs of our particular colony-and the condition of the share or cotton market. But we have all ali certain interest in the Capitulations, which are, to all intents and purposes, our constitution, and no European will but listen with interest to Lord Cromer's proposals as given in his latest report.

Lord Cromer complains-and with justice-that his proposals have been unfairly treated in being described as involving "the abolition of the Capitulations." They should mather be said to constitute a "modification of the Capitulations" by which the British Empire takes the place of fifteen different powers. What then are these proposals? We have not the space to give them in full, but we can give at least a summary which will sbow how they affect the average European resident of Egypt for whose benefit they have been made. 1. Should Lord Cromer's proposals be accepted, instead of legislation by diplomacy in all matters regarding European residents in Egypt we shall liave legislation by a local Council composed entirely of Europeans, and subject to the British and Exyptian Governments. No law now requiring the consent of the puwers can come into force until it has been accepted by a majority of the Council and approved by the above mentioned Government 2. Europeans shall be deprived of no right or privelege which they now enjoy under the Capitulations without any adequa e guar. antee being given against the recurrence of the abuses against which their rights and privileges were intended to guard." 3. The Mixed Courts will to all intents and purposes continue to exist under a local obligation, to administer laws passed by the European Legislative Council and approved by the British and Egyptian Governments. Their internationalism is affirmed and a threefold guarantee is offered that there sball be no break in the continuity of the codes which they administe. These guarantees are : firstly, a proposed declaration of the British and Egyptian Governments, secondly, the international character of the cuncil, and thirdly, doabttul questions to be referred 'to the Hague Tribunal 4. The rights of Europeans accused on criminal charges are secured by a series of guaranteus which will ensure that the future European Criminal Courts will adininister justice in * manner at least as satisfactory" as that of the Consular Courts. 5. Domiciliary visits will not be permitted without the authorization of a magistrate who is the subject of a treaty power and the presence of an officer of the court who is a subject of a treaty power. "In other words when a domiciliary visit is effected in the house of an Englishman, a Frenchman, or a German, resident in Cairo or Alexandria, the process will be similar to that which would have taken place in London, Paris, or Berlin, with the exception that the agents employed in carrying on the search instead of being Englishmen, Frenchmen, or Germans may be of some other nationality." 6. In all cases of arrest a European will have the right to be at once liberated on bail or to be brought before a European magistrate within 24 hours of his arrest. Into the question of the composition of the Council we cannot now go. It is important and interesting, but far more important is ord Cromer's note (p 11) on the duration of the British Occupation of Egypt. Here we have the guarantee that the new system, if adopted, well not be nullified by reason of any sudden reversal of British policy, "the question of the 1 duration of the occupation is left to the discretion of the British Government. It will last as long as that Government considers. it necessary in the interests of all concerned, in the welfare and good government of Egypt”... His Majesty's Government "recognise that the maintenance and development of such reforms as have hitherto been effected in Egypt depend upon the British Occupation. This consideration will apply with equal strength to any changes effected in the regime of the capitulations His Majesty's G verdient therefore wish it to be understood that there is o reason for allowing the prospect of any modifications in that regime to be prejudiced by the existence of the British Occupation of the country. We commend this declaration to the attention of our nationalist critics. It is of great importance to every resident in Egypt, European and native, from the Khedive to the humblest fellah, giving as it does the surest of guarantees that the onward march of Egypt shall not be turned to retreat by the forces of absolutism or reaction.

div.p: The Ministry of Public Instruction has decided to send twelve pupils of the Normal School at Cairo,-six each of the first and second years' classes--to England to complete their studies at an English University. div.p: The Legislative Council will he held on the 10th. inst, in order to deal with the demands of the General Assembly. The demands in question are five viz : 1. To reform the Mehkemeh Shurieh, 2. div.p: The Khedivial Geographical Society have decided to confer the diploma of "membre d'honneur" upon his Royal Highness Louis · Amédée de Savoie Duc des Abruzzes in recognition of the services rendered to geography by him in his voyages, and notably to African geography, by his recent exploration of the chain of the Ruwenzori. Professor Schweinfurth, Honorary President of the Society, and Abbate Pasha will deliver speeches.

div.p: The following agreement has been made between the Egyptian Government and the Cairo Tramway Company - The Tramway Company is authorised to carry its lines across the bridge from Boulao to the island of Ghezireh, to cross the island and the bridge over the Bahr el Aama, in order to reach Embabeh. div.head: ASSOUAN DAM
div.p: In the House of Commons on Monday week Mr. H. C Lea asked the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs whether his attention had been drawn to the resolution come to by the Egyptian authorities to proceed with the increasing of the height of the Assouan dam by seven metres; whether last year doubts were raised by men of scientific eminence as to whether the strains and stresses at present , borne by the Assouan dam had been properly calculated; whether he had satisfied himself as to these fears by inquiry of the best engineering experts ; and, if not, would he consider the advisability of suggesting to the authorities in Egypt the appointment by them of a small committee of scientific men to go thoroughly into the matter, and so obviate the possibility of an accident happening which might cause disastrous loss of life and property Mr Runciman replied that a despatch had · been received from Lord Cromer explaining the reasons which had led the Egyptian Government to arrive at the decision to raise the dam. In due course it would be presented to Parliament. In the meanwhile, it was not desirable to answer questions upon isolated points in connection with the matter.

div.head: TELEGRAPH IN THE SAHARA
div.p: The “Temps” states that it has been decided by the Algerian Government to extend the line which now terminates at Beni-Abbes to Adrar, in the Oasis of Touat. The length of this new line is 248 miles, and the eost is set down at from £12,000 to £16,000. It is understood that the work, which will require about three months to execute, will be taken in hand next autumn. A new form of metallic telegraph pole will be employed, and when this line has been completed a further extension to In-Salah is contemplated, with the ultimate object of crossing the desert.

div.p: Mr. Moore is bringing an action for damages against the three newspapers belonging to Mustapha Pasha Kamel, El Lewa," "The Egyptian Standard," and "L'Etendard" for their allegations of corruption against him. div.head: UM RUS MINES OF EGYPT.
OPERATIONS TO BE DISCONTINUED
div.p: The ordinary general meeting of the Um Rus Gold Mines of Egypt (Limited) was held last week in London. Mr. John Harvey presided and after referring to the history of the mine, he stated that the mining reports seemed to indicate a position which was growing from bad to worse, and those received of late held out no inducement to the company to continue operations. The opinion of the board and of the managers was that operationsshould cease in order to prevent money from being frittered away in useless operations. Sir Henry Bunbury seconded the motion. After a shareholder had expressed strong dissatisfaction with the state of affairs, the report was adopted. By an informal resolution the shareholders present expressed the opinion that the operations should be discontinued and the assets disposed of with a view to the liquidation of the company.

div.head: THE ROYAL VISIT
K.S.C. GYMKHANA
div.p: The last gymkhana of the season was held under most favourable circumstances, being graced by the presence of our Royal visitors, H.H. the Khedive and Lady Cromer, and being favoured by one of the brightest and warmest days we have seen this year. H.H. the Khedive arrived quite early in the afternoon and was present in the royal box in time to witness the first event. It must have been about half past three that the carriage containing the Duke and Duchess of Connaught and Lady Cromer entered the ground, driving across the turf, preceded by mounted policemen and escorted by two officials on bicycles, and in front of the grand stand and enclosure to the box, where they were greeted by the Khedive, Major General Bullock, Sir Vincent Corbett, Sir William Garstin and others. Princess Victoria arrived shortly afterwards and dur ag the afternoon various ladies had the honour of being invited to the royal enclosure. The events of the afternoon were of à most popular and entertaining nature, and though there were several accidents there were none of a serious nature. The jumping competition was most interesting, Captain Leigh's prowess evoking great enthusiasm, and the pig sticking competition caused general amusement, the pig, represented by an inflated water skin at the end of a long rope, proving a most sporting and highly eccentric target. The polo match on donkeys too proved most entertaining, for the humble quadrupeds had no idea of what was expected of them, and anbled about in an aimless fashion, stumbling whenever they could, with a delightful unconcern of the rules of the game. It was a difficult game to follow, even though pace was no object, and the ball was a big one ; but it proved one of the most interesting events of the afternoon, and doubtless afforded the donkeys material for cogitation during the coming months of summer idleness. There was so much to watch and so many people to notice that there was little time to regret the passing of so nany of our late visitors. The stand was full throughout the afternoon, and most of the résidents were to be seen in the enclosure. Mrs and Miss Bullock and Mrs. Findlay were įmong those who finished the afternoon in he royal box, and Lord and Lady Lanesborongh ind Lady Vivian were noticed during the įfternoon the latter with Mrs. Rom who was vearing a most delightful frock of maslin potted with black and with deep black edged orderings of watteau design and colouring. The Misses York were wearing the very prettiest of white mu-lin frocks, and Miss Leverich was also in white with a blue sash. Miss Erskine Shaw who came with Mrs. and Miss Bennett, was much admired in a beautifully fitting semi-Empire frock of biscuit cloth and Mrs. Montague Summer's toilette of vieux rose voile, with passementerie of dull gold about the lace yoke was most becoming Bcth Mrs Nolan and Miss Moore were in muslin, the one having pink ribbons and the other white run through the lace insertions ; and Miss Luck was wearing a sweetly pretty frock of fine black and white striped muslin with a lace corsage showing under the little bolero, The Misses de Villebois were dressed alike in blue silk, and the Misses Çoles were in pink. div.head: Zizinia Theatre
M. De Feraudy
div.p: If circumstances compelled our absence on Monday at the first of a welcome series of plays, we are not conceited enough to ima. gine we owe any apology other than to M. de Féraudy and his company. And it is not a mere shuffling excuse to say that if his Isidore Lechat of ļast Monday was as masterly and vehement as when we last saw him. in the part, the performance was beyond criticism, M de Féraudy is perhaps at his best in "Les Affaires sont les Affaires" and it was a sine quâ non that the play is included in his repertory ; at the same time he no doubt fully realised the boldness of producing it here, for the Lechats, like the poor, are always with us and nowhere more so than in Alexandria ; it is quite on the cards that some were present on Monday and we are sorry to have missed an interesting spectacle, viz the real Lechats' scrutiny of M. de Feraudy's treatment of the subject. We do not for a moment say we have mot any Lechats to equal that of M de Féraudy, or rather of Octave Mirbeau ; they have probably not been victims to circumstances in which to shew such strength of character or it may be they want. the strength of character which would render similar tense and bittar circum. stances feasible. But both the real and stage Lechats (and there is little to choose between them) thanks to M. Mirbeau's ingenuity and M. de Féraudy's remarkable conception of the part, are at any rate free from the hyprocrisy of concealing a love and display of wealth, which is a decided merit. There were no special merits about any of the characters (if such mere talking machines can be so called) in "Paraitre," which was given last night. M Donnay has attempted,like so many modern playwrights, to denounce the shortcomings of society and in particular to break a lance with snobbishness, which is practically co-existent with society. His intention is praiseworthy enough from a moralist's point of view but his way of expressing it in this four-act-five-scene pièce de salon is singularly unconvincing. There is so much irrelovant talk, so many unnecessary persons that it is difficult to get at the backbone of the play at all. Perhaps one is not meant to get there, for everything is done to divert one's attention with a series of intrigues and liaisons of an extraordinary description. Furthermore many of the impersonators should be provided with some palpable cause or other for entering and leaving the stage and for indulging in long and often lugubrious conversation.. The brunt of trying to keep the audience interested fell upon Mmes Van Doren (the injured wife ) Bressan (the transgressing wife) MM. Sévérin (the transgressing husband) and Bauer (the injured husband and incidentally i he brother of the injured wife.) M. de Feraudy's part was quite a supernumerary one and he charmed his audience more by his reposeful speech and gesture than by anything very striking in the shape of dialogue.
